question.text:
Match Column - I with Column - II and select the CORRECT option from the codes given below
 
  Column – I   Column – II
A. FADH2 (i) Phosphoenolpyruvate
B. Electron acceptor (ii) Fumarate
C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase (iii) Cytochrome C
D. Substrate-level phosphorylation (iv) Acetyl CoA

solution.text:
The given columns are based on the chemical reactions involved in glycolysis and aerobic respiration.

Dehydrogenation: In TCA cycle, succinate undergoes dehydrogenation to form fumarate and FADH2.

Cytochrome C: It is a small protein and does the work of electron transfer between complexes in the ETS.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase: It acts as a catalyst in the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvic acid including Coenzyme A and NAD+. 

Substrate-level phosphorylation: The process of formation of ATP, when substrate get converted to products it is called substrate-level phosphorylation. when phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) gets converted to pyruvate, ATP is formed.
